sen.j: 長尾雨山（ながお うざん、 元治元年9月18日 (旧暦)（1864年10月18日） - 昭和17年（1942年）4月1日）は、明治期の日本の漢学者・書家・文人画・篆刻家である。
sen.e: Uzan NAGAO (October 18, 1864 - April 1, 1942) was a Japanese scholar of the Chinese classics, calligrapher, literati painter and Tenkoku artist (artist of seal engraving) of the Meiji period.
Uzan NAGAO (October 18, 1864 - April 1, 1942) was a Japanese scholar of the Chinese classics, calligrapher, literati painter and Tenkoku artist (artist of seal engraving) of the Meiji period.
Uzan NAGAO (October 18, 1864 - April 1, 1942) was a Japanese scholar of the Chinese classics, calligrapher, literati painter and Tenkoku artist (artist of seal engraving) of the Meiji period.

sen.j: 狩野君山・内藤湖南とともに中国学を開花・進展させたひとりに挙げられる。
sen.e: He can be mentioned as one of those who developed and advanced Sinology, as well as Kunzan Kano and Konan NAITO.
He can be mentioned as one of those who developed and advanced Sinology, as well as Kunzan Kano and Konan NAITO.
He can be mentioned as one of those who developed and advanced Sinology, as well as Kunzan Kano and Konan NAITO.

sen.j: 名は甲、字を子生、号 (称号)は雨山の他に石隠・无悶道人・睡道人、斎室名に无悶室・何遠楼・思斎堂・艸聖堂などがある。
sen.e: His first name was 甲 and azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was 子生, and other than Uzan, he had pseudonyms such as Iwagakuri (石隠), Mumon Donin (无悶道人) and 睡道人, and Saishitsu-mei (斎室名) (alias named after the name of one's room) such as Mumon-shitsu (无悶室), 何遠楼, Shisai-do (思斎堂), Sosei-do (艸聖堂), etc.
sen.cmt: 甲→甲子生→子生石隠→Iwagakuri (石隠)无悶道人→Mumon Donin (无悶道人)睡道人→睡道人斎室名→Saishitsu-mei (斎室名) (alias named after the name of his rooms)无悶室→Mumon-shitsu (无悶室)何遠楼→何遠楼 (何遠楼)思斎堂→Shisai-do (思斎堂)艸聖堂→Sosei-do (艸聖堂)全て正しい読み方不明です。
sen.e: His first name was 甲 and azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was 子生, and other than Uzan, he had pseudonyms such as Iwagakuri (石隠), Mumon Donin (无悶道人) and 睡道人, and Saishitsu-mei (斎室名) (alias named after the name of one's room) such as Mumon-shitsu (无悶室), 何遠楼, Shisai-do (思斎堂), Sosei-do (艸聖堂), etc.

His first name was 甲 and azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was 子生, and other than Uzan, he had pseudonyms such as Iwagakuri (石隠), Mumon Donin (无悶道人) and 睡道人, and Saishitsu-mei (斎室名) (alias named after the name of one's room) such as Mumon-shitsu (无悶室), 何遠楼, Shisai-do (思斎堂), Sosei-do (艸聖堂), etc.

sen.j: 通称は槙太郎。
sen.e: His common name was Shintaro.
His common name was Shintaro.
His common name was Shintaro.

sen.j: 高松の人。
sen.e: He was born in Takamatsu.
He was born in Takamatsu.
He was born in Takamatsu.

sen.j: 略伝
sen.e: Brief biography
sen.cmt: 用語統一リストには、”略歴”は”Brief personal history” を使用、と指示がありますが、ここは”略伝”なので、用語登録されている”Brief biography”を使用しました。
sen.e: Brief biography
Brief biography

sen.j: 讃岐国高松藩の長尾勝貞（竹嬾）の長子として香川郡高松（香川県高松市）に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Takamatsu, Kagawa County (Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture) as the first son of Katsusada (Chikuran) NAGAO of Takamatsu Domain, Sanuki Province.
He was born in Takamatsu, Kagawa County (Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture) as the first son of Katsusada (Chikuran) NAGAO of Takamatsu Domain, Sanuki Province.
He was born in Takamatsu, Kagawa County (Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture) as the first son of Katsusada (Chikuran) NAGAO of Takamatsu Domain, Sanuki Province.

sen.j: 幼い頃から父について漢学を受け、天性の詩才を見いだされる。
sen.e: In his childhood, he studied the Chinese classics under his father, and was found to have a natural poetic talent.
In his childhood, he studied the Chinese classics under his father, and was found to have a natural poetic talent.
In his childhood, he studied the Chinese classics under his father, and was found to have a natural poetic talent.

sen.j: 明治21年（1888年）、東京大学文科大学古典講習科を卒業後、岡倉天心に共鳴し東京美術学校の設立に尽力。
sen.e: In 1888, after graduating from Japanese classics studies, the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Letters University, he sympathized with Tenshin OKAKURA and made efforts to establish Tokyo Fine Arts School.
sen.cmt: 東京大学文科大学古典講習科→Japanese classics studies, the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Letters University (古典講習科：定訳不明です）1888年は”東京帝国大学”と呼ばれていた時代ですが、原文通り”東京大学”と訳しました。http://www.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/schema/history.html
sen.e: In 1888, after graduating from Japanese classics studies, the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Letters University, he sympathized with Tenshin OKAKURA and made efforts to establish Tokyo Fine Arts School.

In 1888, after graduating from Japanese classics studies, the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Letters University, he sympathized with Tenshin OKAKURA and made efforts to establish Tokyo Fine Arts School.

sen.j: また美術雑誌「國華」（現在も朝日新聞出版で刊行）の創刊にも協力しその編集も行っている。
sen.e: He also cooperated in the launch of an art magazine 'Kokka' (currently still published by Asahi Shimbun Publications Inc.) and also worked as its editor.
He also cooperated in the launch of an art magazine 'Kokka' (currently still published by Asahi Shimbun Publications Inc.) and also worked as its editor.
He also cooperated in the launch of an art magazine 'Kokka' (currently still published by Asahi Shimbun Publications Inc.) and also worked as its editor.

sen.j: この間、学習院・東京美術学校などで教鞭を執る。
sen.e: In the meantime, he taught at The Gakushuin School Corporation, Tokyo Fine Arts School and so on.
In the meantime, he taught at Gakushuin (educational institution for children of Japanese aristocracy), Tokyo Fine Arts School and so on.
sen.cmt: 民営化されたのは戦後の話なので以下のように変えました。The Gakushuin School Corporation → Gakushuin (educational institution for children of Japanese aristocracy)
sen.e: In the meantime, he taught at Gakushuin (educational institution for children of Japanese aristocracy), Tokyo Fine Arts School and so on.

sen.j: 明治30年（1897年）から勤めた熊本の第五高等学校 (旧制)では夏目漱石の同僚となってよき相談相手となり詩文などでも親交を深めた。
sen.e: At the former Fifth High School in Kumamoto, where Uzan worked from 1897, he became a colleague and good adviser of Soseki NATSUME, and they deepened their friendship through prose and poetry, etc.
At the former Fifth High School in Kumamoto, where Uzan worked from 1897, he became a colleague and good adviser of Soseki NATSUME, and they deepened their friendship through prose and poetry, etc.
At the former Fifth High School in Kumamoto, where Uzan worked from 1897, he became a colleague and good adviser of Soseki NATSUME, and they deepened their friendship through prose and poetry, etc.

sen.j: 明治32年（1899年）、東京高等師範学校教授に転じ、東京帝国大学文科大学でも講師を務め、明治35年（1902年）に職を退官し上海市に移住。
sen.e: In 1899, he became a professor of Tokyo Higher Normal School, as well as an instructor at Tokyo Imperial University, Faculty of Letters University, and he resigned the work and moved to Shanghai City in 1902.

In 1899, he became a professor of Tokyo Higher Normal School, as well as an instructor at Tokyo Imperial University, Faculty of Letters University, and he resigned the work and moved to Shanghai City in 1902.

In 1899, he became a professor of Tokyo Higher Normal School, as well as an instructor at Tokyo Imperial University, Faculty of Letters University, and he resigned the work and moved to Shanghai City in 1902.

sen.j: 当時中国最大の出版社であった商務印書館の招聘に応じて編集顧問となり、中国最初の中等教科書の編纂に従事した。
sen.e: He was invited to be an editorial advisor at Commercial Press, which was the biggest publisher in China of the time, and was engaged in compilation of the first textbook for secondary education in China.

He was invited to be an editorial advisor at Commercial Press, which was the biggest publisher in China of the time, and was engaged in compilation of the first textbook for secondary education in China.

He was invited to be an editorial advisor at Commercial Press, which was the biggest publisher in China of the time, and was engaged in compilation of the first textbook for secondary education in China.

sen.j: 書画骨董に通暁し、大正元年（1912年）には岡倉天心の紹介でボストン美術館の監査委員を委嘱され美術品の選別にも携わっている。
sen.e: He was well-versed in calligraphy, paintings and antiquities, and in 1912, he was appointed an audit commissioner at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, by the introduction of Tenshin OKAKURA, where he was involved in selection of art works.

He was well-versed in calligraphy, paintings and antiquities, and in 1912, he was appointed an audit commissioner at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, by the introduction of Tenshin OKAKURA, where he was also involved in selection of art works.

He was well-versed in calligraphy, paintings and antiquities, and in 1912, he was appointed an audit commissioner at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, by the introduction of Tenshin OKAKURA, where he was also involved in selection of art works.

sen.j: 民国2年（1913年）、呉昌碩が西泠印社の社長に就任するに及んで河井荃廬とともにこれに参加している。
sen.e: In 1913, when Changshuo WU became president of Seirei Insha, he joined it with Senro KAWAI,
In 1913, when Changshuo WU became president of Seirei Insha, he joined it with Senro KAWAI,
In 1913, when Changshuo WU became president of Seirei Insha, he joined it with Senro KAWAI,

sen.j: 大正3年（1914年）に帰国。
sen.e: He returned to Japan in 1914.
He returned to Japan in 1914.
He returned to Japan in 1914.

sen.j: 京都に居（京都市上京区西洞院通丸太町通上ル）を構え、在野の学者として研究と講学をし、文人とて詩書画三昧の暮らしを送った。
sen.e: Taking up a residence in Kyoto (Marutamachi-dori Agaru, Nishinotoin Street, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City), he lived a life absorbed in poetry, calligraphy and paintings as a literatus, while continuing the study and learning as a scholar out of power.

Taking up a residence in Kyoto (Marutamachi-dori Agaru, Nishinotoin Street, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City), he lived a life absorbed in poetry, calligraphy and paintings as a literati, while continuing the study and learning as a scholar out of power.
sen.cmt: 単数形にしました。a literatus → a literati
sen.e: Taking up a residence in Kyoto (Marutamachi-dori Agaru, Nishinotoin Street, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City), he lived a life absorbed in poetry, calligraphy and paintings as a literati, while continuing the study and learning as a scholar out of power.

sen.j: 駐日清国公使の黎庶昌・書記官鄭孝胥・呉昌碩・羅振玉・内藤湖南・狩野直喜・犬養毅・副島種臣などの当時一流の学者や文人と交遊をひろめた。
sen.e: He widely communicated with top scholars and literati of the time, such as Shuchang LI, Qing minister to Japan, Xiaoxu ZHENG, Qing secretary, Changshu WU, Zhenyu LUO, Konan NAITO, Naoki KANO, Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Taneomi SOEJIMA and so on.

He widely communicated with top scholars and literatus of the time, such as Shuchang LI, Qing minister to Japan, Xiaoxu ZHENG, Qing secretary, Changshu WU, Zhenyu LUO, Konan NAITO, Naoki KANO, Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Taneomi SOEJIMA and so on.
sen.cmt: 複数形にしました。literati → literatus
sen.e: He widely communicated with top scholars and literatus of the time, such as Shuchang LI, Qing minister to Japan, Xiaoxu ZHENG, Qing secretary, Changshu WU, Zhenyu LUO, Konan NAITO, Naoki KANO, Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Taneomi SOEJIMA and so on.

sen.j: 詩書画に通じ、文人としての教養を背景にした。
sen.e: He was well-versed in poetry, calligraphy and paintings, and had educational background as a literatus.
He was well-versed in poetry, calligraphy and paintings, and had educational background as a literati.
sen.cmt: 単数形にしました。a literatus → a literati
sen.e: He was well-versed in poetry, calligraphy and paintings, and had educational background as a literati.

sen.j: その書は法帖を重んじすべての書体をよくしたがとりわけ草書に優れた。
sen.e: His calligraphic works closely followed Hojo (a copybook printed from the works of old masters of calligraphy) and were good in any calligraphic styles; however, they were especially excellent in Sosho (the fully cursive style of writing).

His calligraphic works closely followed Hojo (a copybook printed from the works of old masters of calligraphy) and he was good at every calligraphic styles; however, he was especially excellent in Sosho (the fully cursive style of writing).
sen.cmt: 後半の主語がおかしいと思ったので、heにしました。
sen.e: His calligraphic works closely followed Hojo (a copybook printed from the works of old masters of calligraphy) and he was good at every calligraphic styles; however, he was especially excellent in Sosho (the fully cursive style of writing).

sen.j: 漢詩ははじめ国分青厓と同じく｢明の七子の風｣を標榜したがのちには唐詩・宋詩にも影響され独自の詩風を確立した。
sen.e: Concerning Chinese poetry, he initially advocated 'Min no shichishi no kaze' (the styles of the seven leading literati during the Ming Dynasty) like Seigai KOKUBU did, but he was subsequently influenced by Tang Poetry (poetry during the Tang Dynasty of China) and Sung Poetry (poetry during the Sung Dynasty of China), which led him to establish his unique poetry style.
sen.cmt: ｢明の七子の風｣→'Min no shichishi no kaze' (the styles of the seven leading literati during the Ming Dynasty)定訳、読み方不明です。
sen.e: Concerning Chinese poetry, he initially advocated 'Min no shichishi no kaze' (the styles of the seven leading literatus during the Ming Dynasty) like Seigai KOKUBU did, but he was subsequently influenced by Tang Poetry (poetry during the Tang Dynasty of China) and Sung Poetry (poetry during the Sung Dynasty of China), which led him to establish his unique poetry style.
sen.cmt: 複数形にしました。literati → literatus
sen.e: Concerning Chinese poetry, he initially advocated 'Min no shichishi no kaze' (the styles of the seven leading literatus during the Ming Dynasty) like Seigai KOKUBU did, but he was subsequently influenced by Tang Poetry (poetry during the Tang Dynasty of China) and Sung Poetry (poetry during the Sung Dynasty of China), which led him to establish his unique poetry style.

sen.j: 画は水墨画を得意とし、書画の鑑定に精しかった。
sen.e: In paintings, he was good at ink-wash painting and skilled at appraisal of calligraphic works and paintings.
In paintings, he was good at ink-wash painting and skilled at appraisal of calligraphic works and paintings.
In paintings, he was good at ink-wash painting and skilled at appraisal of calligraphic works and paintings.

sen.j: 平安書道会副会長、日本美術協会評議員を務めた他に日本書道学院・日本南画院などに参加した。
sen.e: Other than serving as a vice chairman of Heian Shodokai and a councilor of Nihon Bijutsu Kyokai (Japan Art Association), he also joined Nihon Shodo Gakuin, The Nippon Nanga-in incorporated Association and so on.

Other than serving as a vice chairman of Heian Shodokai and a councilor of Nihon Bijutsu Kyokai (Japan Art Association), he also joined Nihon Shodo Gakuin, The Nippon Nanga-in incorporated Association and so on.

Other than serving as a vice chairman of Heian Shodokai and a councilor of Nihon Bijutsu Kyokai (Japan Art Association), he also joined Nihon Shodo Gakuin, The Nippon Nanga-in incorporated Association and so on.

sen.j: 昭和17年（1942年）4月、京都の自宅にて没する。
sen.e: In April, 1942, he died at his home in Kyoto.
In April, 1942, he died at his home in Kyoto.
In April, 1942, he died at his home in Kyoto.

sen.j: 享年79。
sen.e: The age at death was 79.
The age at death was 79.
The age at death was 79.

sen.j: 昭和40年（1965年）に中国書画についての講演を編集した『中国書画話』が刊行された。
sen.e: In 1965, "Chugoku Shoga Hanashi" ("中国書画話"), which contained his lecture on Chinese calligraphic works and paintings, was published.
sen.cmt: 『中国書画話』→"Chugoku Shoga Hanashi"(『中国書画話』)正しい読み方不明です。
sen.e: In 1965, "Chugoku Shoga Hanashi" ("中国書画話"), which contained his lecture on Chinese calligraphic works and paintings, was published.
In 1965, "Chugoku Shoga Hanashi" ("中国書画話"), which contained his lecture on Chinese calligraphic works and paintings, was published.

sen.j: （筑摩叢書、筑摩書房 跋文は吉川幸次郎）
sen.e: (Chikuma Sosho, Chikumashobo Ltd. The afterward was written by Kojiro YOSHIKAWA)
sen.cmt: 筑摩書房→Chikumashobo Ltd. と訳しました。http://www.chikumashobo.co.jp/company/
